“今天抵达意大利博洛尼亚，现在要去托斯卡纳。这里的热浪非常壮观。长此以往，这些度假胜地从长远来看将没有未来。气候变化正在摧毁南欧。一个时代即将结束。”德国卫生部长卡尔·劳特巴赫 (Karl Lauterbach) 7 月初发布的这条推文在意大利引起了强烈反响。该国旅游部长丹妮拉·桑切（Daniela Santanchè）酸溜溜地反驳说，她感谢劳特巴赫先生选择意大利度假，但意大利政府很清楚气候变化，而且可持续发展是其旅游业管理战略的核心要素之一。

该行业不仅是意大利经济的重要贡献者。欧洲是全球游客最多的地区，到 2022 年，全球 9 亿国际游客中将有 5.85 亿人次来到欧洲。除此之外，国内度假者在欧盟旅游住宿的过夜天数超过了外国人。难怪该行业直接创造了欧盟GDP的 5%，据估计间接创造了 10% 以上。一些国家严重依赖游客的直接和间接贡献，包括克罗地亚（占GDP的 26%）、希腊（18.5%）、西班牙（13.6%）和意大利（10%）。

气候变化导致天气变得更加恶劣，可能会给旅游业带来沉重打击。今年，南欧经历了异常动荡的夏季。 7月，意大利极端炎热的天气引发了席卷西西里岛的野火，该岛首府巴勒莫的气温一度攀升至47°C。再往北，伦巴第大区的冰雹夺去了多人的生命。同样是在七月，在野火吞没罗德岛和科孚岛后，希腊当局不得不从这些岛屿疏散数万名游客。夏季热浪席卷西班牙后，特内里费岛上周遭遇大火，迫使数千人逃离家园。严重洪水淹没了奥地利南部、克罗地亚和斯洛文尼亚。

尽管遭受了严重破坏，但随着度假者在疫情大流行的旅行限制后大量返回，意大利乃至整个欧洲的旅游业今年夏季仍将创下纪录。尽管可能面临危险，但很少有人取消旅行。市场研究员 Demoskopika 表示，今年夏天将有 6800 万人前往意大利度假，其中约一半来自国外。今年的游客人数甚至可能超过 2019 年创下的纪录，当时有 7.43 亿游客从其他国家抵达欧洲目的地。据全球最大的旅游集团德国图尔集团称，尽管价格较高，但夏季预订量仍比一年前高出 6% 左右。

如果游客担心未来几年气候变化的影响，反弹能否持续？韦尼格罗德哈茨应用科学大学可持续旅游专家哈拉尔德蔡司代表许多气候观察家表示，欧洲的天气将变得更加炎热和干燥，未来极端天气事件的可能性将变得更大。除了对遭受洪水或火灾的人们造成可怕的后果外，这还威胁到那些依赖受影响地区旅游业收入和就业的人们的生计。

蔡司先生预测，地中海海滩上经典的“全包式”度假套餐将经历一段艰难的旅程。他认为，闷热的天气会让老年人，尤其是有孩子的人望而却步。威廉港杰德应用科学大学的另一位旅游专家托斯顿·科斯特格斯认为，尽管野火仍然零星发生，但至少在未来五年内，即使在炎热的夏季，游客仍将继续涌向南方。科斯特格斯先生说，年轻人尤其喜欢在阳光下晒太阳。

只要其他选择看起来不那么诱人，地中海的诱惑就可能会持续下去。北方目的地，特别是波罗的海、德国、东欧和斯堪的纳维亚半岛，在夏季高峰期间的需求可能会增加。但这些目的地无法取代南方度假胜地，因为它们不具备大众旅游的条件（许多人无论如何都不想要这种旅游）。对于潜在游客来说，夏季的天气难以预测。但旅行趋势确实会发生变化，尽管速度很慢。 20 世纪 50 年代，德国人最喜欢的度假胜地是穿越边境前往奥地利。直到 20 世纪 80 年代中期，西班牙才接手。专家们一致认为，30 年后欧洲的旅游业将与今天有所不同。

该行业已加入企业的更广泛承诺，到 2050 年成为二氧化碳净零排放者，以实现巴黎气候协议的目标。例如，途易集团希望到 2050 年其整个运营和供应链实现气候中和然而，企业为减轻全球变暖影响所做的这些努力不会产生总体影响。更重要的是，旅游业需要适应气候变化。

短期内，这将是一个采取措施的问题，例如严格管理日益稀缺的水资源、极端天气事件的预​​警系统以及延长假期，托马斯·埃勒贝克（Thomas Ellerbeck）表示，推。例如，他的公司将希腊的预订季节延长至 11 月。 Kirstges 先生认为地中海地区更多的酒店将安装空调（以太阳能为燃料）、饮水机等。游客可以适应早上和晚上外出，以避免中午的高温。

从长远来看，有些人从地中海的金色沙滩转向波罗的海的海滩是不可避免的。但对于度假者来说，还有一线希望，他们要么会发现波罗的海海滩意想不到的美景，要么可能在一年中的不同时间去南方。一些游客转向春季或秋季将有助于缓解过度拥挤的情况，这对居民和那些渴望在相对平静的环境中吸收杜布罗夫尼克、威尼斯、巴塞罗那或其他南欧奇迹文化的游客来说是一个很大的麻烦。 ■

美国的钢铁制造商是当时的大型科技公司，在 19 世纪工业化导致需求猛增时处于企业前沿。 1901 年，十家工业公司合并成立了美国钢铁公司，这是世界上最早的价值十亿美元的公司之一，在接下来的 70 年里，钢铁制造商的业务在两次世界大战中的重整军备的推动下蓬勃发展。那些令人兴奋的日子早已一去不复返了。许多公司，例如美国钢铁公司，使用焦煤在高炉中从铁矿石中冶炼钢铁，要么被收购，要么破产。事实上，8月13日，美国竞争对手Cleveland-Cliffs表示，它已向美国钢铁公司出价73亿美元，其中一半是现金，一半是自己的股票。不久之后，据说世界第二大钢铁制造商安赛乐米塔尔正在考虑竞购。

美国钢铁公司曾经是美国股市的巨头，现在在中型股标准普尔400 指数中表现不佳，克利夫兰克里夫斯也是如此。与此同时，使用电弧炉 ( EAF ) 的公司在小型工厂中利用电力加工废金属，目前占美国产量的 75%，而 1960 年仅为 10%。小型工厂更加环保，建造和运营成本更低，因此即使在经济低迷时期通常也能保持盈利。这转化为可观的利润。 Nucor 和 Steel Dynamics 等小型钢厂运营商最新季度的营业利润率约为 22%，而US Steel 为 12.5%，Cleveland-Cliffs 为 8%。

传统钢铁制造商可能会进一步落后。电炉可以灵活地生产铁路和汽车制造商使用的扁钢以及主要用于建筑业的长材产品。高炉仅限于前者。这使得现任者几乎没有选择。一是拥抱新事物。 2021 年，美国钢铁公司以约 15 亿美元的价格收购了 Big River Steel 小型钢厂，并正在建设另一座小型钢厂，到 2024 年，其钢铁产能从电炉产能增至约 660 万吨，占总产能的 28%。更大胆的举措是收购另一家大型钢铁制造商，以进一步整合高炉。该行业已经高度整合； 2000 年，14 家钢铁制造商占据了大约 80% 的市场份额，而今天只有 4 家。

克利夫兰克利夫斯公司是美国钢铁公司迄今为止唯一确认的竞标者，该公司的表现尤其活跃：2020年，该公司在美国钢铁公司和安赛乐米塔尔公司离开美国时抢购了它们的高炉。与我们钢铁公司合并是一场更大的赌博。它将打造一个炼钢巨头，使其拥有一半的扁钢、60%的汽车市场以及对电工钢的完全控制权。反垄断机构可能认为这是一次过度的整合。政客们可能会更顺从，尤其是在选举临近之际。

代表我们钢铁公司员工的联合钢铁工人工会正在为克利夫兰悬崖而战。工会希望保留高炉，因为它们工会化程度很高，并声称对潜在投标人拥有否决权。美国钢铁公司的老板戴维·伯里特对此提出异议，并拒绝了竞争对手的提议，称其不合理。如果他想让我们钢铁公司恢复昔日的辉煌，他可能很快就别无选择，只能接受。 ■

; Thu, 24 Aug 2023 12:47:07 GMT /内容/2517mp6c1jn22atfasvam73os8kkf8f3 https://www.economist.com/business/2023/08/24/americas-steelmakers-forge-a-future-together The benefits of a good workplace mentoring scheme are undeniable

《指环王》中的G安道夫、《星球大战》中的尤达以及伊恩·弗莱明早期詹姆斯·邦德小说中的 M 都扮演着导师的角色，为不那么世故的人提供明智的建议和指导。在现实生活中，就像在小说中一样，传授通过经验和年龄（尤达已经 900 岁，甘道夫已经 1000 多岁）获得的智慧的价值变得越来越重要。即使大流​​行引发的“大辞职”导致的就业市场动荡逐渐消失，保持员工的快乐和忠诚也符合公司的利益。一个好的指导计划可以达到这个目的。

职场辅导长期以来一直是一种非正式的活动，伪装成咖啡机旁的聊天或与服务时间较长、资历较高的同事一起去酒吧。即使是最成功的人也会发现拥有善于倾听的耳朵是对公司武器库的有用补充。三十多年来，比尔·盖茨一直向另一位亿万富翁沃伦·巴菲特寻求建议。另一位科技大亨彼得·泰尔 (Peter Thiel) 认为，法国博学者兼兼职哲学家雷内·吉拉德 (René Girard) 是他最伟大的灵感来源之一。

近年来，企业一直在寻求正式的安排，其明显的回报是培养联系感和忠诚度，并帮助技能的转移和发展。目的是通过分享知识和经验来支持员工并增强他们的信心。在最好的情况下，当导师和被指导者之间存在真正的融洽关系时，这样的安排可以帮助后者提出新的想法并帮助他们应对问题。

那么企业如何制定最佳的指导计划呢？要让他们工作，一定程度的化学反应是必不可少的，同样重要的是，无论年龄差距和背景如何，都必须高度尊重寻求建议的人。毛里齐奥·奥尔拉基奥 (Maurizio Orlacchio) 是连锁酒店四季酒店 (Four Seasons) 的前经理，他将自己的职业生涯归功于与导师的关系，这位导师是一位年长的高管，教他如何激励员工和他自己。

计划应自行管理，由初级方牵头安排始终保密的讨论。最好让员工选择他们最愿意与之讨论职业轨迹的人，无论他们在公司的职位如何。所请求的导师可能会受宠若惊，但仍会拒绝。

如果你想成为一名有价值的导师，不要一开始就主动提供建议。如果您正在接受指导，请不要寻找个人问题的解决方案（恋爱关系失败、头皮屑）或要求保释金。但任何其他与工作相关的事情都应该开放讨论。 “我感觉不稳定，这一切都让人难以接受”就像谈论你的长期职业前景一样合理。

公司越来越认识到与乐于助人的同事面对面交流的重要性。斯坦福大学的尼古拉斯·布鲁姆（Nicholas Bloom）利用自疫情爆发以来数百个组织的数据发现，对新员工的指导是让员工每周工作两到三天的关键原因。高盛首席执行官大卫·所罗门（David Solomon）在推动全面重返办公室时也回应了这一点。

尽管高盛做出了努力，但在家工作已成为大流行后的一种固定方式。因此，虚拟辅导仍然发挥着作用。与任何在线关系一样，信任和融洽的关系需要更长的时间才能建立。无论边界设置得多么清晰，当会议在 Zoom 上开着摄像头进行时，都不可避免地会看到个人空间。巴特比建议，要表现得相当聪明，不要从冰箱里拿啤酒。面对面见面时看似自然的事情在网上并不总是能很好地翻译。

反向指导也很流行。将一名初级员工与一位对多样性和其他代际差异的理解可能需要进修课程的高管进行匹配可能会有好处。经验丰富的首席财务官能从千禧一代身上学到多少东西，还有争论的余地，但最好的指导关系始终是双向的。

无论是午餐、饮料还是在停车场聊天，如果辅导能够培养更友好的文化、留住员工并培养有才华的员工，那么它的好处是不可否认的。想想尤达的平静举止和银河智慧，而不是他神秘的言语模式。我们的想法是，即使不是绝地大师，至少也能在你感到工作陷入困境时找到一个可以倾诉的人。有时，分享一杯咖啡就像挥舞光剑一样强大。 ■

; Thu, 24 Aug 2023 12:47:07 GMT /内容/2630v46plssneiota3kq3g5jjqv97ng https://www.economist.com/business/2023/08/24/the-benefits-of-a-good-workplace-mentoring-scheme-are-undeniable Corporate America risks losing the Supreme Court

如果美国公司要向最高法院举杯，那么理想的时机是在 6 月份，当时九位法官在一项愉快的判决中一致裁定杰克丹尼公司胜诉，其中包括对戏仿、糟糕的双关语和，其中，狗屎。该商标侵权案的焦点是一种形状像杰克丹尼啤酒瓶的犬类玩具，名为“坏西班牙猎犬”。在威士忌制造商的黑白花丝下面，“老 7 号品牌田纳西酸麦芽威士忌”字样被“田纳西地毯上的老 2 号”字样所取代。杰克丹尼公司并没有感到好笑，美国商会也是一个有影响力的游说团体，称此案“不是什么好笑的事情”。撰写这份意见书的自由派法官埃琳娜·卡根 (Elena Kagan) 忍不住高兴起来，她表示，此案涉及“狗玩具和威士忌，这两个项目很少出现在同一个句子中”。不过，她的结论是非常严肃且支持大企业的：模仿并不是商标侵权的笼统借口。

对一些人来说，这个决定符合一种模式。去年，南加州大学的李·爱泼斯坦 (Lee Epstein) 和弗吉尼亚大学法学院的米图·古拉蒂 (Mitu Gulati) 使用 1920 年至 2020 年企业盈亏数据，将首席大法官约翰·罗伯茨 (John Roberts) 领导的最高法院描述为“可能是”一个世纪以来最亲商的法庭”。他们认为，这不仅仅是因为共和党占多数。民主党任命的人也经常投票支持商业，就像他们在杰克丹尼裁决中所做的那样。

这种对商业友好的描述可能过于简单化了。正如学者们承认的那样，评估美国最高法院的方法有更细致的方法，例如查看案件所阐述的法律原则。由于前总统唐纳德·特朗普在法庭上塞满了极端保守派，其6比3的右转甚至可能削弱了其对商业的支持。事实上，法院最近的裁决（其中一些裁决受到了对宪法的原旨主义解读的影响，无视 235 年后企业的运作方式），这些裁决让美国企业界感到困惑，在从州际贸易到平权行动等问题上做出了不利于其利益的裁决。由于它变得不那么务实，法庭也变得更难以预测。企业也会因不确定性而退缩。

历史表明法院的意识形态结构如何影响美国商业。爱泼斯坦女士和古拉蒂先生的数据显示，在 20 世纪的大部分时间里，对商业最友好的法院是 1921-30 年间威廉·霍华德·塔夫脱 (William Howard Taft) 领导下的法院。自由放任的时代，针对工会的案件占主导地位。 20 世纪 50 年代和 1960 年代是企业成功的最低谷。此后，随着自由市场思维的重新兴起，企业胜率有所提高。公民联合诉联邦经济委员会案是罗伯茨法院早年亲商环境的象征，该判决认为企业拥有宪法权利，可以在政治竞选活动中随意花钱。

不过，最近的裁决让气氛变得黯淡。其中两个直接违背企业利益的行为具有巨大的潜在溢出效应。为维护加利福尼亚州禁止出售来自过度封闭的生猪的猪肉的法律，法院于 5 月驳回了州外农民（几乎生产全国所有猪肉）声称该法律（称为第 12 号提案）违反了法律的企图。通过损害州际贸易来违反宪法。为了支持农民，商会试图证明加州的先例可以允许其他强大的州对其境外的企业实施监管，从而使各州的贸易巴尔干化，但没有成功。

另一个案件“马洛里诉诺福克南方铁路公司” ，涉及公司可以在哪里被起诉的问题。人们早已确定，公司可能会在受伤发生地或其所在地面临法律挑战。但法院 6 月份的裁决维持了宾夕法尼亚州一项独特的法律，即使伤害发生在其他地方，也可以在法院起诉公司。如果其他州通过类似的法律，这就增加了“论坛购物”的可能性。

从企业角度来看，同样令人担忧的是与业务无关的重大判断所带来的影响。各公司正在准备应对六月决定结束高等教育中基于种族的平权行动的影响。在判决之前，从苹果到 Uber 等 80 多家公司共同提交了一份法庭之友陈述，表达了促进大学多元化对工作场所的好处。自裁决以来，一些人担心，对防止工作场所歧视的《民权法》第七章的类似挑战可能会危及他们的多元化努力。

法院可能仍会安抚部分商界人士。自由市场顽固分子对其反击总统乔·拜登监管攻击的努力表示赞赏。即将推出的两个案例将探讨行政国家的轮廓。其中一个问题涉及监管机构消费者金融保护局的未来。另一个案例将审查一个有近 40 年历史的 Chevron 先例，该先例指示法官只要其解读合理，就应遵循政府机构对模棱两可的法律的解释。

别让法庭出去

然而，有一种令人不安的紧张气氛。虽然部分私营部门欢迎对行政权力的限制，但去年具有里程碑意义的西弗吉尼亚州诉环境保护局案限制了美国环保局监管燃煤发电厂温室气体排放的能力，阻碍了向更清洁燃料形式的转变。许多企业支持。批评者认为这是保守派绝大多数在替补席上制定政策。正如美国企业界对共和党部分人士丧失常识感到遗憾一样，它可能也会对最高法院的干预主义更加强烈感到遗憾。当然，是时候换上杰克丹尼的加强筋了。 ■

; Thu, 24 Aug 2023 12:47:07 GMT /内容/7da29n0blu65gkloeqcv0pc4vo7efgmh https://www.economist.com/business/2023/08/24/corporate-america-risks-losing-the-supreme-court Arm’s flotation could revive the market for IPOs

无论聚会多么疯狂，这种罕见的宿醉感一直持续到第二年。然而，在 2021 年创纪录的狂欢之后，首次公开募股 ( ipo ) 的投资者仍然感到头疼。根据数据公司 Dealogic 的数据，在长达一年的狂欢中，他们在 2021 年向全球股市上市投入了约 6000 亿美元。这个数字是 2007 年金融危机爆发前的两倍多，是 2000 年互联网泡沫膨胀的近三倍。但随后通胀飙升、廉价货币的终结和市场的崩溃让庆祝活动付诸东流。在一些地方，上市几乎消失了：2022 年美国首次公开募股的募集资金比上一年下降了 90% 以上。 2023 年至今，这种阴沉的情绪仍在持续（见图表）。

音乐可能很快就会再次响起。 8 月 21 日，英国芯片设计公司 Arm 终于提交了一份初步招股说明书，准备在备受期待的纳斯达克交易所上市，预计将于 9 月上半月上市。估值可能在 600 亿至 700 亿美元之间，这将是近两年来美国上市规模最大的一次。

不仅仅是 Arm。尽管 8 月份出现波动，但股市近一年来一直在上涨：美国大型企业的标准普尔500 指数较 10 月份的低点上涨了 24%。 MSCI最广泛的全球股票指数也上涨了 24%。这样的牛市对私营企业的老板们带来了不可避免的诱惑。鉴于价格上涨如此之多，也许现在是时候向公众投资者出售该公司的大部分股票并获得大量资本作为回报了。

美国银行的詹姆斯·帕尔默表示，重要的是，几个月来波动性也一直受到抑制。这降低了潜在的流通者在启动长达数周的上市过程后却看到市场暴跌以及即将发行的股票价值随之下跌的可能性。另一家银行摩根大通的阿洛克·古普特 (Aloke Gupte) 则更加乐观。他说，最近几周，在他的团队的帮助下上市的公司的工作节奏已经“从第二档升至第五档”。

与此同时，已经上市的产品表明市场渴望更多产品。 Oddity Tech 是一家美容公司，或许不可避免地会使用人工智能 ( ai ) 来开发其产品，该公司于 7 月 19 日在纳斯达克上市。它看到对其产品的需求远远超过供应。该公司出售了价值 4.24 亿美元的股票，投资者下了超过 100 亿美元的订单。 Arm 首次公开募股后，杂货配送集团 Instacart、软件公司 Databricks 和身份验证公司 Socure 都可能跟进上市。

如果这种稳定的滴水要变成一股急流，就需要三个有利于它的发展。第一个是更清晰地了解利率走向。一位资深银行家表示，对此的困惑是上市以及并购等其他交易在 2023 年上半年恢复缓慢的主要原因。随着美联储数十年来最快的紧缩周期仍在进行中，她认为，一些美国地区性银行摇摇欲坠，濒临倒闭，猜测长期利率的最终结果就像是在黑暗中冒险。除了确定公司的融资成本之外，这也是首次公开募股投资者衡量其潜在回报的最终基准。因此，如果不太清楚“无风险利率”将在哪里确定，就不可能有信心地对新一批股票进行定价。

现在，市场和经济学家越来越普遍地认为，美联储加息已经或接近结束。然而，利率将在多长时间内保持高位的不确定性仍然存在，这主要是由于美国经济令人惊讶的弹性。主要是由于这一原因，十年期国债的收益率（可能是投资者最重要的基准）自 5 月初以来上升了 0.8 个百分点，达到 4.2%。在这一措施开始解决之前，首次公开募股仍将难以定价，因此数量稀少。

认真恢复上市所需的第二个因素是企业自身信心的增强。 “一段时间以来，我一直认为市场准备就绪会先于公司准备就绪，”美国银行的帕尔默先生表示。他说，成功的上市需要企业向监管机构、投资者和研究分析师做出一系列保证。该公司不仅将提供下一季度的财务业绩指引，而且可能还会提供未来一年的财务业绩指引。

只要地缘政治紧张局势，尤其是中美之间的地缘政治紧张局势持续高涨，严重依赖跨境贸易的企业就会发现很难提供这样的保证。与此同时，几乎所有国家都受到通胀将在何处稳定以及世界主要经济体是否避免（而不仅仅是推迟）衰退的不确定性的阻碍。一些公司，比如生命周期有限的私募股权基金所拥有的公司，可能别无选择，只能在不确定性的迷雾中跃跃欲试并上市。但那些拥有选择自由的人更有可能等到它解除。

新的首次公开募股热潮的最后一个（如果是显而易见的）要求是，现在准备上市的公司必须成功地做到这一点。咨询公司安永的雷切尔·杰林 (Rachel Gerring) 表示，至关重要的是，这意味着他们的股票最终将以投资者预期的价格出售，然后从该价格开始上涨。 2021 年许多流通股的情况恰恰相反，这为之前的繁荣敲响了丧钟：很少有IPO投资者愿意在不从新上市相关的股价“上涨”中获益的情况下打开支票簿。从这个意义上说，Arm 的上市具有图腾般的重要性。如果其股价大幅上涨，其他公司也会迅速跟进；如果它失败了，他们可能不会。

无论何时实现，下一批IPO可能会与 2021 年的类别有很大不同。随着利率触底的令人兴奋的日子已经过去，投资者将看重“更安全”的前景。这意味着大公司优于小公司，利润优于收入增长，经验丰富的高管优于新手，易于建模的商业计划优于更具投机性的企业。摩根大通的古普特先生认为，这些偏好反映在现在准备上市的公司群体比 2021 年更加多样化。他表示，虽然上一波浪潮由科技公司主导，但下一波浪潮将涉及更多的工业、能源转型、以消费者为中心的医疗保健服装。

所有人都同意，不太可能恢复到当前干旱之前的惊人交易速度。各国央行不再向市场注入大量流动性，过去 18 个月的加息仍可能使许多经济体陷入衰退，而处于数十年来最昂贵水平的美国股市也可能会崩盘。但古普特表示，“如果没有什么能扰乱现状”，那么应该有相当数量的公司寻求在 2024 年上市。那么，所有人的目光都集中在 Arm 身上，看看这辆苹果车是否能继续上路。 ■

; Thu, 24 Aug 2023 10:30:32 GMT /内容/ub6sej5g639tdhd76cpdu2t3igd60t5b https://www.economist.com/business/2023/08/24/arms-flotation-could-revive-the-market-for-ipos Arm’s public listing is set to break records

8月 21 日，芯片制造商 Arm 申请首次公开募股 ( IPO )，该公司的设计为全球大多数智能手机提供支持，这可能是今年规模最大的一次。这家日本科技集团软银集团旗下的英国公司所走的道路并不平坦。 2016 年，软银以 310 亿美元收购了当时在伦敦证券交易所上市的 Arm。四年后，一项以 400 亿美元出售给另一家芯片制造商英伟达的提议被竞争监管机构否决。现在，一场重磅上市即将到来，这也标志着自 2022 年以来一直处于休眠状态的IPO市场的复苏。

Arm 最快将于 9 月初在美国科技股密集的纳斯达克上市。软银将保留多数控制权并将所有收益收入囊中。首次公开募股文件没有具体说明 Arm 打算筹集多少资金或该芯片制造商的价值，尽管软银在 8 月份斥资 160 亿美元购买了该集团科技投资工具 Vision Fund 持有的 25% 股份，使 Arm 的估值约为 64 美元十亿。它可能会寻求约 600 亿至 700 亿美元，即年销售额的 21 至 25 倍左右。这将使其接近 Nvidia 的高市盈率（见图表），8 月 23 日，Nvidia 公布季度营收较上年同期增长 101%，击败分析师，证实了其作为人工智能淘金热领军者的地位。 ' 已经寄予厚望了。对下个季度的预测更加乐观。

Arm 芯片设计的普遍性似乎证明了其丰厚的估值是合理的。与设计、制造和销售芯片的竞争对手不同，Arm 只经营知识产权。它通过授权其设计来赚钱，客户可以根据需要修改设计，并从每个制造的芯片中抽取一小部分。使用 Arm 的现成设计，公司可以以自己设计成本的一小部分来构建处理器。结果，它的芯片无处不在。

全球 99% 的智能手机均采用其技术。在从工业传感器到智能烤面包机或其他任何现在连接到互联网的设备中，65% 的处理器都采用了它的设计。在汽车领域，Arm 拥有 41% 的市场份额，即使在利润丰厚、长期由英特尔主导的云计算市场，基于 Arm 的处理器也占芯片销量的 10%。

人工智能的繁荣让 Arm 的前景更加光明。 8 月初，Nvidia 推出了 Grace Hopper，这是一款将基于 Arm 的中央处理单元 ( cpu ) 与其图形处理单元 ( gpu ) 结合在一起的新芯片。该芯片有望运行更大、更快版本的语言模型，这些模型根据互联网上的文本进行训练，以产生类似人类的输出。正如伯恩斯坦经纪人萨拉·鲁索 (Sara Russo) 指出的那样，随着人工智能从数据中心转向消费者应用程序，将需要能够使用更少能源运行人工智能功能的设备。 Arm 在低功耗、高性能芯片方面的专业知识应该有助于它满足需求。

其他科技趋势看起来不那么令人鼓舞。首先是需求低迷。 Arm 的大部分销售额来自智能手机、汽车和其他联网设备的处理器。这些芯片的销售最近低于预期。 Qualcomm, an American chipmaker that specialises in smartphone processors, recently reported a 23% drop in sales in the latest quarter compared with a year earlier. It expects the downturn to drag on until at least the end of the year. The forecast for automotive chips is similarly gloomy. Expanding demand from ai will not be enough to offset a drop-off in Arm's core products.

Arm's position as the only supplier of easy-to-use chip designs is also in peril from risc-v , an open-source alternative developed at the University of California, Berkeley. risc-v designs are available to anyone without a licence or fee. Alan Priestley of Gartner, a market-research firm, believes it is a “growing threat” to Arm. For now risc-v serves the lower end of the market—sensors, connected devices and automotive chips. But as the technology improves, the promise of licence- and royalty-free designs for expensive smartphone and data-centre processors could prove a problem for Arm. In the year to March 2023 all its revenues came from licensing ($1bn) and royalties ($1.6bn).

A reliance on Arm China—a separate entity—for a quarter of its revenues is another cause for concern for investors. In its filings Arm admits that it is “particularly susceptible” to tensions between China and America. In December Arm chose not to license its designs for a high-end cpu to Alibaba, a Chinese e-commerce giant, for fear that it would fall foul of a ban imposed by America last year on selling certain cutting-edge chips in China.

The question is whether the hype around ai means that investors pay less attention to such worries. When the deal to sell Arm to Nvidia fell through in 2022, Son Masayoshi, the founder of SoftBank, vowed to take Arm public in the “the largest ipo in semiconductor history”. ai exuberance in a market starved of blockbuster ipo s may make his wish come true. ■

; Wed, 23 Aug 2023 15:39:35 GMT /内容/9decq4oju4f4co9jueff61r52eqrh1s1 https://www.economist.com/business/2023/08/23/arms-public-listing-is-set-to-break-records America’s corporate giants are getting harder to topple

A ttend any business conference or open any management book and an encounter with some variation of the same message is almost guaranteed: the pace of change in business is accelerating, and no one is safe from disruption. Recent breakthroughs in artificial intelligence ( ai ) have left many corporate Goliaths nervously anticipating David's sling, and fearing the same fate as Kodak and Blockbuster, two giants felled by the digital revolution.

“The Innovator's Dilemma”, a seminal book from 1997 by Clayton Christensen, a management guru, observed that incumbents hesitate to pursue radical innovations that would make their products or services cheaper or more convenient, for fear of denting the profitability of their existing businesses. In the midst of technological upheaval, that creates an opening for upstarts unencumbered by such considerations. Yet America Inc has experienced surprisingly little competitive disruption during the internet age. Incumbents appear to have become more secure, not less. And there is good reason to believe they will remain on their perches.

Consider the Fortune 500, America's largest firms by revenue, ranging from Walmart to Wells Fargo and accounting for roughly a fifth of employment, half of sales and two-thirds of profits. The Economist has examined the age of each firm, taking into account mergers and spin-offs that make the group look artificially young.

We found that only 52 of the 500 were born after 1990, our yardstick for the internet era. That includes Alphabet, Amazon and Meta, but misses Apple and Microsoft, the middle-aged tech titans. Only seven of the 500 were created after Apple unveiled the first iPhone in 2007, while 280 predate America's entry into the second world war (see chart 1). In fact, the rate at which new corporate behemoths arise has been slowing. In 1990 there were 66 firms in the Fortune 500 that were 30 years old or younger. Since then the average age has crept up from 75 to 90.

One explanation for this is that the digital revolution has not been all that revolutionary in some parts of the economy, notes Julian Birkinshaw of the London Business School. Communications, entertainment and shopping have been turned on their heads. But extracting oil from the ground and sending electricity down wires look much the same. High-profile flops like WeWork, a much-hyped office-sharing firm now at risk of collapse, and Katerra, which tried and failed to redefine the construction business by using prefabricated building components and fewer middlemen, have discouraged others from trying to disrupt their respective industries.

Another reason is that inertia has slowed the pace of competitive upheaval in many industries, buying time for incumbents to adapt to digital technologies. Although 65% of Americans now bank online, nearly all the banks they use are ancient—the average age of those in the Fortune 500, including JPMorgan Chase and Bank of America, is 138. Fewer than 10% of Americans switched banks last year, according to Kearney, a consultancy. That stickiness has made it difficult for would-be disrupters to build scale before incumbents imitate their innovations. A labyrinthine regulatory system that favours big institutions with well-staffed compliance departments helps. The insurance industry, also dominated by geriatric giants like aig and MetLife, is much the same.

The pattern is not unique to financial services. Walmart, America's mightiest retailer, almost missed the rise of e-commerce. David Glass, its boss in the 1990s, predicted that online sales would never exceed those of its single largest retail warehouse, according to a recently published book, “Winner Sells All”, by Jason Del Rey, a journalist. Nonetheless, Walmart's financial heft and enormous customer base gave it the chance to change course later. Only Amazon now sells more online in America. The recent growth of electric vehicles from Ford and General Motors, America's two largest carmakers, offers another example. Their bulky balance-sheets have allowed them to spend heavily on reinventing their businesses at a time when raising capital is becoming more difficult for newcomers.

A third explanation for the endurance of America's incumbents is that their scale creates a momentum of its own around innovation. Joseph Schumpeter, the economist who coined the phrase “creative destruction”, first argued that economic progress was propelled mostly by new entrants, noting in “The Theory of Economic Development” in 1911 that “in general it is not the owner of stage coaches who builds railways”. By the time he published “Capitalism, Socialism and Democracy”, his magnum opus of 1942, he had changed his mind. It was, in fact, big firms—monopolies, even—that drove innovation, thanks to an ability to splash cash on research and development ( r&d ) and quickly monetise breakthroughs using existing customers and operations, spurred on by a constant fear of being toppled.

America's tech titans offer the quintessential illustration. Alphabet, Amazon, Apple, Meta and Microsoft invested a combined $200bn in r&d last year, equivalent to 80% of their combined profits and 30% of all r&d spending by listed American firms. Less obvious examples abound, too. John Deere, America's largest agricultural-equipment firm, founded in 1837, leads the way in innovations like driverless tractors and clever sprayers that use machine learning to spot and target weeds. Its ambition is to make farming fully autonomous by 2030. After snatching laid-off techies from Silicon Valley it now employs more software engineers than mechanical ones.

Incumbents and newcomers also often play complementary roles in innovation. William Baumol, an economist, wrote in 2002 of a “David-Goliath symbiosis” in which radical breakthroughs generated by independent innovators are then enhanced by established firms. A paper in 2020 by Annette Becker of the Technical University of Munich and co-authors split r&d spending by a sample of firms into more exploratory “research” and more commercially oriented “development”, and found that the relative weight of research fell with firm size. Likewise, a paper in 2018 by Ufuk Akcigit of the University of Chicago and William Kerr of Harvard Business School found that patents generated by big firms were less radical and more focused on incremental improvements to existing products and processes.

That division of labour may help explain why many startups are bought by established firms. John Deere's acquisition in 2017 of Blue River, for example, gave it the technology behind its clever weed sprayer, which it was then able to sell through its vast network of distributors. Over the past decade 74% of venture-capital “exits” in America were via such acquisitions, according to PitchBook, a data provider (see chart 2). That is up from next to none in the 1980s, leading to warnings of a plague of “killer acquisitions”, with big firms eating their potential future rivals.

Such cases do occur, but are rare. A study in 2021 by Colleen Cunningham, then at the London Business School, and co-authors found that 5-7% of acquisitions by drug companies, which rely heavily on startups to top up pipelines, looked suspect. Most of the time, folding into an established giant is simply the most efficient way for an innovative new firm to bring its breakthroughs to the world.

A final explanation for the lack of competitive disruption relates to demographics. “Young firms are generally built by young people,” notes John Van Reenen of the London School of Economics. Between 1980 and 2020 the share of America's population aged between 20 and 35 fell from 26% to 20%. The rate of new business formation dipped from 12% to 8% in the same period (see chart 3). In a study of 2019 comparing variations in population growth and new business formation across states in America, Fatih Karahan of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York and co-authors concluded that falling population growth accounted for 60% of the decline in the business-entry rate over the past 40 years.

Application rates to start new businesses in America surged in late 2020 after plunging in the early months of the pandemic, and have since remained well above pre-pandemic levels. That entrepreneurial burst has mostly focused on hospitality and retailing, which were hammered by covid, and over time may peak, especially as pandemic-swollen household savings dwindle. Optimists will hope that the recent flurry of investment in ai startups can sustain the momentum. Even if it does, the corporate giants of the past may well remain on top. ■

; Thu, 17 Aug 2023 13:33:27 GMT /内容/mor8jpfl00no7540rev8a2bd37v09hf6 https://www.economist.com/business/2023/08/17/war-in-ukraine-has-triggered-a-boom-in-europes-defence-industry America’s courts weigh in on how firms resolve liability claims

T he long-running legal battle over America's opioid epidemic was reignited when, on August 10th, the country's Supreme Court said it would review an earlier settlement secured by Purdue Pharma, a main character in the saga. Back in 2021 a federal judge had approved a bankruptcy plan for Purdue—the maker of OxyContin, a highly addictive painkiller—under which the business was to be restructured as a public-benefit company with all future profits going towards settling claims from victims and funding addiction-treatment programs. Members of the Sackler family, which owns the drugmaker, were to contribute $4.5bn (later increased to $6bn) towards the settlement.

At issue is a controversial legal arrangement called a “third-party release”, which shields entities associated with bankrupt companies from liability even if they have not filed for bankruptcy themselves. In Purdue's case, the Sacklers were granted immunity from any future opioid-related claims, an unsatisfying outcome for those who blame the family for their role in fuelling the opioid crisis.

American firms have been turning to bankruptcy courts to resolve product-liability claims since the 1980s, but in recent years have done so in increasingly creative ways. In 2021, faced with thousands of lawsuits alleging that its talcum powder caused cancer, Johnson & Johnson ( J & J ), a pharmaceutical giant, deployed the “Texas two-step”—a legal manoeuvre that shifts a company's liabilities to a separate entity and then declares that entity bankrupt. J & J established a Texan subsidiary, called LTL Management, assigned more than 40,000 talcum-powder claims to it, then filed it for bankruptcy. Last year Aearo Technologies, a subsidiary of 3 M , a Minnesota-based conglomerate, was hit with some 260,000 lawsuits related to allegedly defective earplugs. By declaring its subsidiary bankrupt, 3 M was also able to limit its exposure. Both companies deny the allegations against them.

Lawyers for the companies argue that the bankruptcy courts are more efficient than the tort system for both defendants and plaintiffs. It is easy to see the appeal for businesses. Declaring bankruptcy pauses all litigation, prevents the filing of any new lawsuits and brings all claims under one roof, while the third-party release arrangement absolves the parent company of future related liabilities. Some claimants also prefer the speedier resolution promised by bankruptcy courts to the slower and more uncertain payoffs on offer in the tort system.

Critics point out that bankruptcy is intended for companies that are genuinely insolvent, not merely burdened with lawsuits. 2022 年，强生公司销售额达 950 亿美元，派发股息 120 亿美元，持有现金 250 亿美元，仅拨出 90 亿美元来解决滑石粉索赔问题。 3 M is similarly unlikely to be sunk by the lawsuits against it. Jared Ellias of Harvard Law School argues that, by dumping their liabilities into a subsidiary, companies facing mass litigation are asking for the benefits of bankruptcy without truly submitting to the courts. For victims seeking a hearing, as well as compensation, the mechanical nature of bankruptcy proceedings minimises discussions of a company's wrongdoing, which tort battles do not.

Courts are increasingly sceptical of the companies' arguments. In June a judge in Indiana rejected the bankruptcy filing of 3 M ’s subsidiary Aearo, noting that the company was using bankruptcy as a “litigation-management tactic”. A month later a New Jersey bankruptcy court quashed LTL ’s insolvency plea, pointing to the deep pockets of its parent, J & J . The Supreme Court's scrutiny of Purdue's third-party releases may be the most consequential of all. According to Pamela Foohey, a professor at Cardozo School of Law, Purdue “really pushed the envelope” in how it used bankruptcy. If the justices agree and limit the use of third-party releases, corporations may find that bankrupting smaller subsidiaries to fight sprawling lawsuits is no longer the saving grace it once was. ■

D EAR Robin , I was delighted when you commissioned me to prepare this report for you after our discussion at the club. As a newly appointed chief executive at a Fortune 500 company, a thrilling yet perilous adventure awaits you. I commend your wisdom in choosing to hire a management consultant to guide you on your way.

I, naturally, would have been ideally positioned, given my many years of experience serving your company's principal rival. Alas, the time comes in every man's life when he must hang up his hat and retire to his home in the Bahamas. As my swan song, I have thrown together, as requested, a few thoughts on how to handle my kind. I hope you find the attached 120-page PowerPoint presentation useful. Below you will find a brief summary.

Be ready for the “bait and switch”: Do not be fooled by the eloquent veterans who will turn up to your office to plead for your business. The work will mostly be done by clever but pimply 20-somethings, armed with two-by-two matrix frameworks recycled from client to client. What they lack in wisdom will be made up for in long hours. You need not feel sorry for them. They are cocooned in a shell of fancy meals, lavish hotels and private drivers—at your expense.

At first you will find them to be of no use at all—detrimental, even—as they harry your management team with endless questions and urgent requests for data. Eventually, they will win you over with their brains and gumption—or be quietly replaced. Meanwhile, those grey-haired senior partners will pop by from time to time.谨防。

Watch out for “land and expand”: We consultants are masters of the clandestine sale. If you hire us for a two-month project, it will assuredly take 12. By the time it ends, our tentacles will have spread. Ask for a new company strategy, blink, and we will be cutting your costs, fixing your IT systems and tinkering with your supply chain.

Like many other bosses, you may one day tire of our eye-watering rates and decide to poach the cleverest consultants for yourself. We will happily oblige. The most reliable missionary for the merits of consulting is one of our own. The more senior, the better. Hire them, but do not give them the cheque book.

Question everything: Every self-respecting consultant knows that big recommendations demand big numbers. As a rule, divide everything you see by two. Never trust a benchmark; I made up most of mine. And carefully read those endless notes at the bottom of charts. That is often where the dirtiest secrets are buried. Be doubly dubious of any consulting reports your underlings happen to commission, especially when they recommend a bigger budget for said underling.

Take none of the blame: As a freshly minted chief executive, you are undoubtedly brimming with ideas. Many of them are terrible. Some may prove catastrophic. Among the valuable services offered by management consultants is the human shield. Make sure your board knows it was they who recommended the disastrous new product line or the overpriced acquisition. You always had your doubts, but trusted their illustrious reputations. Equally, your consultants may, from time to time, stumble upon a good idea. You thought of it first.

Experiment with polygamy: Your consultants will do their utmost to woo you into exclusivity. There will be much talk of “long-term partnership”. Yet it is a one-sided monogamy they seek. Fidelity is not in a consultant's nature. Chances are they are already advising your competitors, with only the thinnest of Chinese walls between teams.

Follow their example and hire their rivals, too. Ideally, sit them in adjacent rooms at your offices. Consultants are fiercely competitive, and nothing will better spur them on to even longer reports than seeing their nemeses wandering the halls of your company. If bored, invite representatives of two warring firms to a meeting and watch them tussle for your favour.

As I look back on my career, I am not too proud to admit that I have occasionally fleeced the odd firm. But I maintain that my profession is a noble one. “Impact”, after all, is our industry's watchword. (Admittedly, I never was quite clear what it meant, but you cannot deny it sounds lofty.)

One final thought to conclude: there is never a problem too big or small for a consultant. That I can confirm from experience. Your bill, including expenses, is attached.祝你好运。 ■

; Thu, 17 Aug 2023 13:33:27 GMT /内容/ja66opr4dhaiu6veutbii4sctnuatui5 https://www.economist.com/business/2023/08/17/a-retiring-consultants-advice-on-consultants Flying taxis could soon be a booming business

P aris has long been at the heart of the history of flight . It is where the Montgolfier brothers ascended in the first hot-air balloon in 1783, and where Charles Lindbergh completed the first solo transatlantic aeroplane journey in 1927. Next year, if all goes to plan, Paris will be the site of another industry first when Volocopter, a German maker of electric aircraft, launches a flying-taxi service during the Olympic Games. At the Paris Airshow in June the company, and some of its rivals, paraded a new generation of battery-powered flying machines designed for urban transport.

The electrification of aviation has often been written off as a pipe dream, with batteries presumed too heavy a substitute for hydrocarbon fuel in an airborne vehicle. For longer journeys, such as Charles Lindbergh's across the Atlantic, that may well be true. Yet upstarts like Volocopter are betting that electrification can unlock a boom in demand for clean and quick aerial journeys over shorter distances.

The main form of flying taxi under development, called an electric vertical take-off and landing (e VTOL ) aircraft, looks somewhat like a super-sized drone, carrying between one and four passengers, plus a pilot. Powered by batteries, they are both quiet enough to quell complaints in crowded cities, and fast: capable of up to 300kph, enough to comfortably outpace a car, especially one stuck in traffic. Indeed, optimists hope the absence of traffic in the sky will also make e VTOL s well-suited to autonomous operation. They could prove handy for transporting goods, too.

That vision has inspired giddy predictions. Morgan Stanley, an investment bank, reckons global spending on e VTOL s could hit $1trn by 2040. Volocopter is not the only player staking out the terrain. According to the Vertical Flight Society, a non-profit, more than 400 contenders have developed e VTOL designs. Joby, a Silicon Valley startup, has already raised $2bn from investors. Archer, another, hopes to have “hundreds or thousands” of its craft flying by the 2028 Los Angeles Olympics.

Despite the enthusiasm, challenges remain. One is technical certification, which is turning out to be a lengthy process as aviation regulators grapple with an entirely new form of aircraft. Some manufacturers, such as Volocopter and EHang, a Chinese firm, are close to having machines in service. In April Volocopter opened an assembly plant in Germany. But others are further off. Late last year Joby was forced to push back its launch by a year to 2025 thanks to, among other things, regulatory delays. Many have even longer to go.

The bigger question is whether the business of flying taxis will be viable. e VTOL s currently range in price from $1m to $4m. Although their cost may come down as the industry develops, they are likely to remain expensive pieces of machinery. Brian Yutko of Wisk, a maker backed by Boeing, says that flying-taxi rides will be “accessible to the masses”. Joby promises that its fares will be comparable to catching a taxi. Yet some studies suggest the cost could end up as high as $7 per km, many times a regular taxi fare. Even without a pilot, flying taxis may remain a convenience affordable only to a lucky few.

An alternative opportunity for electrification lies with small fixed-wing planes designed to transport a few dozen passengers over distances of a few hundred kilometres—for instance, between nearby cities. Heart Aerospace, a Swedish firm, plans to have a 30-seater plane with an all-electric range of 200km in the air by 2028. In September last year Eviation, an Israeli company, successfully tested a nine-seater electric plane with a range of 400km.

According to McKinsey, a consultancy, air travel accounts for just 8% of journeys between 150km and 800km in America. In Europe it is only 4%. Most such journeys are taken by car, even in Europe, where buses and trains are more readily available. That creates a big opportunity for environmentally friendly short-haul flights, especially given that 90% of America's population and 50% of Europe's live within a 30-minute drive of a regional airport. Expect plenty more experiments with electric aircraft in the years ahead. ■
